items.title: HIV breakthrough drug priced out of reach for those who need it most | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>The UN agency leading the world's response to HIV and AIDS, is making an urgent call to action: UNAIDS wants a groundbreaking HIV prevention drug to be made available to everyone who needs it. The drug, Lenacapavir, requires just two injections a year and has shown remarkable success in trials. 
But there's a problem: it currently costs each patient more than forty thousand dollars per year - that's far too expensive for most. 

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: Has Lukashenko silenced the Belarussian opposition? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>Exit polls in Belarus indicate that longtime ruler Alexander Lukashenko has won the country's presidential election. As polls close there, election authorities are already reporting that Lukashenko has captured 87-point-6 percent of the vote. Lukashenko - who has close ties to Moscow -  has now been in power since 1994. Election observers say the vote was largely orchestrated - rigged - and that any meaningful opponents are in prison or exiled.

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: How Arab countries are responding to Trump's 'clean out' Gaza remarks to expel Palestinians
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>On Saturday, US President Trump suggested that Palestinians be expelled from the Gaza Strip to "clean out" the territory. Trump called the Gaza Strip a "demolition site" and that ethnically cleansing Palestinians from the enclave could be a temporary or a long-term arrangement. President Trump said he had spoken to Jordanian King Abdullah about Jordan taking in Palestinians, and that he would speak to Egyptian President el-Sissi on Sunday for Egypt to do the same. Trump's "clean out" remarks have stirred controversy, as any forced expulsion of Palestinians would violate international law and jeopardize the creation of a Palestinian state.  

Chapter Breakdown: 
0:00 Palestinian Islamic Jihad announces release of Arbel Yehud
0:40 Joost Hiltermann, MENA Program Director at the International Crisis Group, on Trump's suggestion to 'clean out' Gaza and how Arab countries are responding 

#trump #forcedexpulsiongaza
#egypt

items.title: Palestinian Islamic Jihad announces release of Israeli civilian prior to next hostage-prisoner swap
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>The militant group Palestinian Islamic Jihad in Gaza says it will free Israeli civilian hostage Arbel Yehud before the next planned swap where Israel is to release Palestinian prisoners and detainees in exchange for Hamas returning Israeli hostages. According to the terms of the Israel-Hamas ceasefire agreement, Arbel Yehud should have been handed over by Hamas this past Saturday. Hamas, however, delayed the release over what they called technical reasons. Israel has blocked tens of thousands of Palestinians from returning to their homes in northern Gaza, and says their return is conditional on Yehud's release.

DW speaks to journalist Balig Sladeen.

#arbelyehud
#israelihostages #palestinianislamicjihad


For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: Israeli forces remain in southern Lebanon past withdrawal date, kill at least 22 Lebanese | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>Tensions have erupted along the Lebanon-Israel border as Israeli forces remain in southern Lebanon past the agreed withdrawal deadline under a fragile ceasefire with Hezbollah. According to Lebanese health officials, at least 22 people were killed and over 80 injured when Israeli troops fired on residents attempting to return to their homes.  The deadly incident is likely to enflame the humanitarian crisis for the 112,000 displaced Lebanese.

#dwnewsshorts #lebanon #ceasefirelebanon

items.title: Can the EU compete with China’s rail plans? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>A deadly accident at a train station in Serbia has put a spotlight on China’s outsized role in the Balkans and Hungary, particularly its funding for large rail projects. Europe is now trying to keep up, but is it enough? DW looks at a geopolitical competition centered around rail, trade and the future orientation of a region on the EU’s periphery. 

Chapters:
00:00   Intro – Anger and ambitions
01:34   Albania – The race to modernize
06:49   North Macedonia – Nation at a juncture
11:49   Serbia – Promise and tragedy
16:56   Hungary – A reliance on China
21:12   End – What we’ve seen

#chinarailway #chineseinvestments
#balkans


For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: Thousands across Germany protest far-right AfD: How are they so popular? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>Protesters in Germany took to the streets to oppose the country's popular far-right party. The demonstrations took place across the country Saturday as the Atlernative for Germany party kicked off its election campaign. In the run-up to next month's federal election, polls show the AfD in second place with about 20 percent support.

items.author: DW News
items.content:

items.title: Israeli troops kill civilians returning to southern Lebanon villages | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>The Lebanese Health Ministry says at least two people are dead in southern Lebanon after Israeli soldiers fired on residents carrying Hezbollah flags. 
The ministry said another 31 people had been injured near the border with the Israeli-occupied Golan Heights. Tensions have been rising in the area as residents have been returning to their homes despite the presence of Israeli forces. The troops were set to withdraw by Sunday under a ceasefire agreement between Israel and Iran-backed Hezbollah militants. But Israel said on Friday they would remain there longer.

00:00 Israeli soldiers fire on Lebanese villagers
00:42 Journalist Karim El-Gawhary reports from Kafr Kila in Southern Lebanon

items.title: Growing crackdown on dissent raises alarms in Uganda | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>Fears are growing in Uganda of an escalating crackdown on dissent. In just the past few months, opposition leader Kizza Besigye has been charged with treason, his lawyer was imprisoned, and several activists have been arrested for criticizing the government online. DW correspondent Julius Mugambwa has more from Kampala, on what critics are calling a dangerous new phase of repression.

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: US issues broad freeze on foreign aid, excepting Israel and Egypt | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>The Trump administration has issued a halt to nearly all existing foreign aid, with the exception of that flowing to Israel and Egypt. That's according to a State department memo seen by US media outlets. The freeze stems from an executive order signed by Trump within hours of taking office, ordering a 90 day pause in foreign development assisstance in order to review efficiency and consistency with his foreign policy.

items.title: Israel says Gazans' return to north conditional on 'arrangement' of Israeli civilian's release
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>Four female soldiers held captive in Gaza for nearly 500 days have been reunited with their families. They were released by Hamas in return for 200 Palestinian prisoners and detainees held in Israeli jails. It was the second exchange since a fragile ceasefire took effect last weekend to pause the 15-month-long war. The exchange triggered jubilation among both Israelis and Palestinians.

items.title: Israel releases 200 Palestinian prisoners and detainees | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>Israel has freed 200 Palestinian prisoners and detainees, the second such release under a ceasefire agreement between Israel and the militant group Hamas, which came into effect last Sunday. The Red Cross is facilitating the exchange. Buses carrying some of the freed Palestinians arrived in the occupied West Bank, while others who had been serving life sentences were transferred to Egypt.

items.title: Zelenskyy brushes off Putin's stated readiness for peace talks as 'manipulation' | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>Ukraine's President Volodymr Zelenskyy has dismissed comments from Russian President Vladimir Putin that he is ready for talks to end the war in Ukraine. Zelenksyy characterized Putin's comments  as "manipulation." Putin gave an interview to state TV, praising US President Trump. He also said he and Trump had a pragmatic and trusting relationship and suggested they should meet to discuss ending the Ukraine war.

Meanwhile there are media reports that the US is halting foreign aid to almost all countries for 90 days. According to a leaked internal memo from the US State department, only two countries -  Israel and Egypt are exempt from the freeze.

#ukrainerussiawar #trump #zelenskyy
